title: The Fed Should Speak English for a Change
summary: Its long-awaited policy review, expected this year, should also reconsider the 2% inflation target.. Predicting the Federal Reserve's interest-rate decisions is a loser's game. But I'll make one 2020 forecast with confidence: The Fed will release its long-awaited "review" of monetary policy strategy, tools and communications-probably by June.

title: The FTC Acts as Both Prosecutor and Jury
summary: Facing the abuse of the administrative state, my company decided to sue.. It's hard to appreciate the right to a fair trial until that right is taken away from you. Yet that's what the Federal Trade Commission is trying to do to my company, Axon Enterprise , which produces body cameras and other law-enforcement technology.

title: Pompeo Explains the Iran Policy
summary: And he promises to focus on competition with China and better relations with Russia.. Washington

title: 'Why We Can't Sleep' Review: Uncertain at a Certain Age
summary: Women may have once felt a shiver of mortality at 40, but rarely were they also anguished by that unwritten novel or unstarted business.. The midlife crisis has long belonged to men. The revelation that life is finite is apparently so startling to 40- and 50-something males that many behave badly, often by trading in their wives and cars for flashier models with more curb appeal. But as Ada Calhoun writes in "Why We Can't Sleep," middle-aged women are busily closing this angst gap. Squeezed by aging parents and young children, plagued by rising housing costs and declining job stability, ever more American women are waking up in the middle of the night to ask themselves, "Where did I go wrong?"

title: Let Bloomberg Be Bloomberg
summary: Far from apologizing, he should defend what his policies have done for African-Americans.. Just before Michael Bloomberg threw his billions into the ring for the Democratic presidential nomination, the former New York City mayor did what most political consultants probably told him he needed to do. He appeared at a black church in Brooklyn, where he apologized for the New York City Police Department's use of a tactic popularly known as stop-and-frisk.

title: Boy Scouts Face Landmark Sex-Abuse Lawsuit
summary: Plaintiffs hope district's new statute-of-limitations law can apply to abuse that occurred in other states. A group of men who allege they were sexually abused when they belonged to the Boy Scouts of America filed a lawsuit in Washington, D.C., against the organization, testing the limits of the district's new statute-of-limitations law.

title: Killing of Iranian General Brings Iraq's Divided Shiites Closer
summary: Vote calling for foreign forces to leave country reflects dynamic shift after targeted U.S. strike. The targeted killing of Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani has united Iraq's fractious Shiite political groups in opposition to the U.S.

title: Notable & Quotable: Gervais
summary: 'If ISIS started a streaming service, you'd call your agent, wouldn't you?'. From Ricky Gervais's monologue at the Golden Globe awards, Jan. 5:

title: In Past Retaliation, Iran Has Aimed for Soft Targets
summary: Previous attacks have targeted Israeli diplomats in Georgia, India and Thailand and tourists in Bulgaria. In the wake of the U.S. strike against one of Iran's top military commanders last week, Iranian leaders have pledged to retaliate, seeding expectations that Tehran will launch tit-for-tat attacks on U.S. personnel or American allies.

title: New Year, Old Problems for European Banks
summary: 2020 is likely to be another difficult year for Europe's major lenders as economic growth remains weak and technology costs mount. Most new years start with a hopeful view of what can be achieved in the months ahead, but there is little in 2020 for investors in European banks to get excited about.

title: Boeing Considers Raising More Debt as Costs Climb From MAX Crisis
summary: Compensation and maintenance costs rise as grounding stretches toward one-year mark. Boeing Co. is examining plans to raise more debt to bolster finances strained by the mounting fallout from the grounding and halted production of its 737 MAX, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Call it the Facebook Effect, As More Tenants Flock to Far West Side
summary: Debevoise's new headquarters, which it expects will open in 2022, will be at Tishman Speyer's new development, the Spiral. New York City landlords don't have to land a new lease with a major tech firm to reap the benefits of the industry's expansion in the city.

title: Pompeo Tells McConnell He Definitely Won't Run for Senate
summary: Secretary of State informs Senate majority leader he won't seek seat from Kansas. WASHINGTON-Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met Monday with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to say definitively he wouldn't run for the Senate in Kansas this year, according to people close to the two men.

title: Treasury-Management Startup HighRadius Valued Above $1 Billion
summary: Iconiq Capital led the $125 million round in HighRadius, which specializes in accounts receivable software and treasury management. Startup HighRadius Corp. has been valued at more than $1 billion in a funding round, in the latest high-priced deal in the financial technology sector.

title: 'Beetlejuice' Keeps Selling Out as Show Faces Closing
summary: Musical based on 1988 Tim Burton movie is set to end its run at the Winter Garden on June 6. The musical "Beetlejuice" features a joke-filled number that dubs itself "a song about death."

title: IRS Personal Income-Tax Audits Drop to Lowest Level in Decades
summary: Just 0.45% of individuals were audited in 2019, following years of budget cuts. WASHINGTON-Individual taxpayers are half as likely to get audited as they were in 2010, after tax enforcement by the Internal Revenue Service fell to the lowest level in at least four decades.

title: Trump Administration Plans Roll Back of Low-Income Housing Rules
summary: Change allows cities to address shortages with their own plans; critics say move dismantles desegregation efforts. The Trump administration plans to unveil new rules on Tuesday that will roll back Obama-era efforts to prod local governments into building more low-income housing in affluent areas, a policy that was intended to help undo decades of housing discrimination but also created a mountain of paperwork for many local officials.

title: New Charge in UAW Corruption Investigation Specifies Racketeering
summary: The charge is the first to specifically mention racketeering in the yearslong investigation into corruption and embezzlement at the union. Federal prosecutors filed a new charge against a former United Auto Workers official Monday, alleging the defendant was involved in an embezzlement scheme that was part of a wider racketeering enterprise at the union.

title: Boeing Reassigns Staff as Spirit Eyes Furloughs
summary: Aerospace giant doesn't plan to furlough any workers when it suspends production of the 737 MAX in mid-January. Boeing Co. said it would reassign as many as 3,000 workers that make the 737 MAX, and its biggest supplier announced plans for voluntary layoffs ahead of a planned production halt of the grounded jetliner.

title: Juul Appoints an Interim Finance Chief in Shuffle
summary: E-cigarette company says Guy Cartwright, who took over as CFO in October, will now focus on restructuring efforts. Juul Labs Inc. is shuffling its leadership ranks, appointing an interim chief financial officer and putting his predecessor in charge of the e-cigarette maker's $1 billion restructuring effort.

title: Iran Confrontation Could Draw in U.S.-or Push It Away
summary: Trump is sending thousands more troops to the Mideast. But in the long run, the reduction of an American presence in the region could continue. The great question hanging over the dangerous new confrontation between the U.S. and Iran is as simple as it is profound: Is this clash going to deepen America's long entanglement in the Middle East-or is it the kind of watershed event that actually will begin drawing it to a close?

title: Bosch Deploys AI to Prevent Attacks on Cars' Electronic Systems
summary: German engineering company tackles simple tactics used to fool AI systems, such as tape on a road sign. Germany-based engineering company Robert Bosch GmbH is using artificial intelligence to reduce the risk that hackers will be able to trick cars' electronic systems into misinterpreting road signs.

title: Alphabet Stock Off to Strong Start in 2020
summary: Monday's gains fueled by bullish note from research firm; shares outperform broader market. Shares of Google parent Alphabet Inc. lagged behind other big technology companies last year, but they have rallied to start 2020 as investors expect new Chief Executive Sundar Pichai to put his stamp on the tech giant.

title: Quantum Computing Remains a Challenge for Tech Firms
summary: Some machines are still unable to outperform regular computers, despite promise of more processing power. In the race to lead quantum computing, some big technology companies and startups are discovering that the road to market remains longer than planned despite years of often heavy investment.

title: Stocks Inch Higher as Investors Assess Mideast Tensions
summary: Investors are anxious about the possibility of more violence across the Middle East. U.S. stocks turned higher and oil prices gave back some of their gains Monday as investors assessed the recent escalation in geopolitical risk in the Middle East.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Rise as Investors Assess Mideast Tensions
summary: Services-sector data indicates economy remains robust. U.S. government bond prices fell after economic data reinforced optimism about the service sector and as investors weigh concerns about escalating tensions between the U.S. and Iran.

title: American Airlines Reaches Deal With Boeing Over MAX Grounding Costs
summary: Boeing has earmarked $6.1 billion so far to pay customers that operate the aircraft. American Airlines Group Inc. said Monday that it has reached a deal with Boeing Co. to be compensated for damage from the grounding of the 737 MAX last year.

title: Fear of War Sends Gold to Highest Price Since 2013
summary: Precious metal extends recent rally on escalating U.S.-Iran tensions. Gold jumped to its highest level in almost seven years with tensions between the U.S. and Iran escalating, the latest example of investors favoring the safe-haven metal to protect against a market downturn.

title: Pence Says Guaidó Is Venezuela's 'Only Legitimate President'
summary: Vice president spoke to opposition leader by phone for 10 minutes Monday. WASHINGTON-Vice President Mike Pence spoke by phone with Venezuela's Juan Guaidó and reiterated the U.S. position that Mr. Guaidó is the country's "only legitimate" leader, a senior administration official said.

title: Democrats Still Raise Hands for Radical Plans
summary: Warren wins endorsement of world's insurer; media slow to understand 'public option'.. Former presidential candidate and Obama Administration housing secretary Julián Castro has endorsed Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts for President. And for some reason she seems grateful.

title: Puerto Rico Hit by 5.8-Magnitude Earthquake
summary: The U.S. territory has experienced a flurry of seismic activity since Dec. 28. A 5.8-magnitude earthquake shook Puerto Rico early Monday morning, toppling a famed stone arch formation, causing landslides and damaging homes in the U.S. territory already hit by a number of tremors in recent weeks.

title: Oil Gains on Threat of Iraq Sanctions
summary: Crude prices gain after Trump over the weekend threatened Iraq with sanctions. The prospect of U.S. sanctions against Iraq added another variable to oil traders' calculus, increasing the uncertainty around future oil supplies as tensions mount in the Middle East.

title: Weinstein Faces Sex-Crime Charges in Los Angeles
summary: New Los Angeles charges against movie mogul come on first day of New York City criminal trial. Former Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein was charged with sex crimes in Los Angeles on the day that his criminal trial on similar accusations opened in New York.

title: 'Bridget Riley' Review: The Varieties of Visual Experience
summary: A retrospective at London's Hayward Gallery revels in the pleasures of sight itself..

title: Borden Dairy Files for Bankruptcy
summary: The 163-year-old milk producer becomes second major industry player in two months to seek protection from creditors. Borden Dairy Co., a 163-year-old milk producer known for its spokes-cow Elsie, has filed for bankruptcy with plans to erase millions of dollars in debt from its books, becoming the second major player in the industry to seek protection from creditors in two months.

title: Tariffs and the Future of U.S. Manufacturing
summary: The economic facts speak for themselves: Tariffs and trade wars are affecting manufacturing employment and causing an uptick in consumer and commercial prices.. Your editorial "How Tariffs Hurt Manufacturing" (Dec. 31) is on the mark. Tariffs have had a negative impact on manufacturers, including the household and commercial products industry, which develops products that Americans depend on for health and hygiene. Many of the products our members manufacture rely on aerosol technology and require large amounts of high-quality imported steel and aluminum. The tariffs have made it more difficult and costly to access these materials and slowed innovation, which has negatively affected aerosol can and component manufacturers-an example of the downstream industry the Federal Reserve study references.

title: Is Marijuana Fueling a Public-Health Crisis?
summary: Proponents of recreational marijuana push the false narrative of a tax windfall for governments and improved safety for users while ignoring the harms: mental-health issues, addiction, acute and chronic lung disease, domestic violence and more.. Regarding your editorial "The Vaping-Marijuana Nexus" (Dec. 26): Tobacco, marijuana and vaping companies mislead the public on the clear harms associated with wider use of today's higher-THC-content marijuana and inhaling substances other than clean air. Opponents of expansion of marijuana availability acknowledge concerns about disparate enforcement of drug laws. But the costs to society from legitimizing the addiction industry far outweigh the benefits. Meanwhile, proponents of recreational marijuana push the false narrative of a tax windfall for governments and improved safety for users while ignoring the harms: mental-health issues, addiction, acute and chronic lung disease, domestic violence and more.

title: Sanctuary Counties Defend Gun Rights and Federal Law
summary: The sanctuary-county movement might delay the Democrats' agenda and provide time for Virginia voters to repel attacks on the Constitution should they choose to do so.. Your editorial "Second Amendment 'Sanctuaries' " (Dec. 30) highlights a movement by many counties in Virginia to preserve the Second Amendment rights guaranteed in the U.S. Constitution. These rights are in danger because of the stated intent of the Democratic governor and legislators. The proper way to battle their coming attack on the Constitution is to defeat them at the polls, but this will take time and enormous damage can be done before the next election. The sanctuary county movement aims to delay the Democrats' agenda and provide time for Virginia voters to repel attacks on the Constitution should they choose to do so.

title: Distinguishing Intimidation From Protected Free Speech
summary: In Virginia v. Black (2003), the Supreme Court ruled that one can't use individual speech rights for the purposes of intimidation.. Myron Magnet's "'Hate Crime' Is Only a Step Away From Thoughtcrime" (op-ed, Jan. 2) is based on a fallacious conflation of so-called hate speech and speech deliberately designed to instill fear. In Virginia v. Black (2003), the Supreme Court ruled that one can't use individual speech rights for the purposes of intimidation. By Adolpho Martinez's own admission, his "speech"-stealing a rainbow flag from a church and burning it in front of a strip club-was designed to intimidate, to target a group's core identity, their "pride." While we shouldn't excuse thought-policing, this isn't one such case. This was an act deliberately designed to terrorize.

title: Mideast Tensions Threaten Strained U.S. Wheat Exports
summary: Farmers are already struggling following trade war with China and tough weather last year. Rising tensions in the Middle East threaten to make a tough export market for U.S. wheat growers even harder to crack.

summary: Request under war-powers resolution concerns White House notification to Congress about killing of Iranian general. summary: High-end restaurants invite diners to bring several of their own vintages; 'We expect decorum'. summary: As container ships get bigger, drug smugglers are growing bolder in hitching rides on commercial supply chains. Global shipping companies are wrestling with apparent growing demand in a sector that they don't want and that has law enforcement authorities around the world on high alert.

summary: Ride-share giant came under scrutiny for possible Foreign Corrupt Practices violations in 2017. The Justice Department has closed an inquiry into whether Uber Technologies Inc. violated a U.S. law prohibiting bribes to foreign government officials, the ride-sharing company said.

title: The Six Best Designed Items This Month
summary: From Pomellato's sculptural "My Honeymoon" ring to a Bard exhibition on Eileen Gray, everything in the design universe that's entranced our editors this month. Pomellato's new My Honeymoon ring, part of the brand's Armonie Minerali collection, is a marriage of two hard stones-carnelian and white agate-joined by a strip of orange sapphires and set on a rose-gold band. The ring's bold tones echo the words of Gio Ponti, the Milanese architect and designer whose abiding love of color inspired the pieces. "Everything in the world must be colorful," Ponti wrote in 1952. "Color is life." Pomellato ring, price upon request, pomellato.com

title: Roundup Ruled the Farm, Now Its Maker Has a Challenger
summary: Resume Subscription. DECATUR, Ill.-Before it was targeted by tens of thousands of plaintiffs in lawsuits, Roundup was the king of the field-the world's most heavily used weedkiller. title: When Clemson's Unbeaten Football Stars Lost a Game
summary: The Tigers' football team is so dominant on the gridiron that the only time several players have lost a game in college is in intramural basketball. Without hesitation, he lobbed it to a teammate standing wide open: long snapper Patrick Phibbs.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond Strikes Real-Estate Deal

summary: The kickoff to awards season reveals an industry uneasily coping with disruption.

title: Trump Repeats Threat to Target Iranian Cultural Sites
summary: President Trump also said U.S. forces won't exit Iraq unless the Iraqi government reimburses the U.S. for a joint air base. ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE-President Trump repeated his threat that the U.S. could target Iranian cultural sites if tensions between the two countries escalate further.

title: Venezuela's Maduro Ousts Opposition Head of National Assembly
summary: The president's allies replaced Juan Guaidó with their own lawmaker. CARACAS, Venezuela-President Nicolás Maduro took over the last independent institution in Venezuela on Sunday when his allies replaced the opposition head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, with their own lawmaker in a maneuver that was condemned from Washington to Latin America.

title: New York State Will Spend $45 Million for Protection at Religious Schools and Institutions
summary: Announcement by Gov. Cuomo follows anti-Semitic attacks, including Hanukkah stabbing in which five were wounded. New York state is spending $45 million for security at religious schools and institutions, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced Sunday during a solidarity march organized by Jewish leaders in response to anti-Semitic attacks.

title: Five Killed, Dozens Hurt in Pennsylvania Turnpike Crash
summary: The crash occurred early Sunday in Westmoreland County and involved a tour bus, three tractor trailers and a passenger car. Five people were killed and dozens injured in a multivehicle crash on the Pennsylvania Turnpike early Sunday, officials said.

title: Iran Says It No Longer Will Comply With Nuclear Enrichment Limits
summary: Decision marks latest step to scale back compliance, comes as huge crowds mourn military leader killed in U.S. airstrike. Iran said Sunday it no longer will comply with limits on uranium enrichment under its 2015 nuclear pact, as hundreds of thousands gathered across the country to mourn the death of a military leader killed Friday in a U.S. airstrike in Iraq.

title: Europe Tries to Balance Iran and the U.S. After Strike
summary: Politicians fear hostilities could endanger their troops and spark conflicts that unleash a new wave of migrants. BRUSSELS-Escalating steps by Tehran and Washington are raising the pressure on European leaders to pick sides in a conflict they have been seeking to defuse for months.

title: Blue Eggs and Salt? Restaurant Freebies Get Fancy
summary: Compliments of the chef could mean anything these days. At Tocqueville, an upscale French and contemporary American restaurant in Manhattan, diners pay $22 for squash soup, and $175 for an eight-course meal. Sometimes, they leave with a half a dozen pale blue eggs from heritage breed hens favored by the restaurant. For those, they pay nothing.

title: U.S. Regulators Mull Ordering Extra Training for Boeing 737 MAX Pilots
summary: FAA earlier rejected such training mandates. Federal aviation regulators are considering mandatory flight-simulator training before U.S. pilots can operate Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jets again, according to government and industry officials familiar with the deliberations, a change that would repudiate one of the plane maker's longstanding arguments.

title: Mississippi Prisons on Lockdown After Violence Leaves Five Dead
summary: State says one inmate is back in custody after two were discovered missing from a facility. Mississippi prisons remained on lockdown Sunday as officials sought to reassert control in the correctional system after eruptions of violence over the past week left five inmates dead.

title: N.Y. Assembly GOP to Pick New Leader After Kolb's DWI Charge
summary: Kolb was charged with driving while intoxicated after allegedly driving vehicle into ditch on New Year's Eve. Republicans in the Democrat-dominated New York state Assembly will start the legislative session with a new leader after Brian Kolb, who spent the last 10 years running the minority conference, said he would step down from the post.
